posts.name: EricRehder
posts.cooked:
AprilTag sensing is sensitive to Left/Right position. But distance from camera to the AprilTag is often not very sensitive. We are interested in adding a Lidar to measure distance from the robot to the wall that the AprilTag is on.

How can multiple sensor estimates of field position be integrated?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
EricRehder:

How can multiple sensor estimates of field position be integrated?

There are many ways. Let’s start by breaking the problem down.

First, a single lidar measurement provides a linear distance from the wall, to the pose of the sensor on the field.

The sensor’s pose is generally assumed to be three components - an X/Y coordinate on the field, and a rotation. WPILib wraps these up into a Pose2d class.

Given only a single, accurate lidar measurement, there still many possible poses which could have produced that measurement.

You’ll need some way to constrain down which pose you assume produced the lidar measurement. This could include only trusting the measurement while in a specific are of the field (perhaps, aligned with a side of the reef?). It could also involve adding additional sensors - a gyro, or another lidar for example.

Once you have the pose you think produced the measurement, it’s important to remember that all measurements have noise. In reality, there’s a pose that most likely produced the measurement, but other poses near by that also might have produced the measurement (with the probability of the pose being the real one dropping off as you get further from the most-likely point).

Applying a filter to the measurement is one way to decrease the impact of this probability - basically, you use multiple measurements to confirm the pose before using it.

Getting multiple measurements requires that you either have faster sensors, more sensors, or wait for for the sensors to supply more data.

In all cases, as long as the sensors are supplying information in the same reference frame (IE, all produce a Pose2d ) a simple strategy is to take a weighted average of sensors. Pick your weights to represent how much you trust each source of data.

A Kalman Filter (a common recommendation in these cases) takes more steps to formalize this process, also usually including information from your motor power and previous estimates of pose to make an “optimal” guess of current pose.

Two key Lidar-specific considerations:

The field walls are made of clear polycarb, which is usually somewhat scuffed up. This can have some unexpected scattering/transmission effects, depending on the wavelength of laser used.

Other robots and field obstacles might block the line of sight from the lidar to the wall.

Having a strategy for when to or not trust the lidar measurement will be key.

Does all this sound hard? It definitely is!

If you’re willing to assume this is an X/Y problem (your real goal is “better pose” and you’ve incorrectly assumed the solution is “add lidar”)…

Have you done root-cause analysis to determine why one dimension is more accurate than the other with apriltags?

Why not use two apriltag estimates to improve the accuracy?

posts.name: Asher Olgeirson
posts.cooked: Is your camera mounted head-on? Apriltag distances can be off if you look straight ahead. Also, why not mount multiple cameras so that you get a left-right estimate from each side?

posts.name: EricRehder
posts.cooked:
Have you done root-cause analysis to determine why one dimension is more accurate than the other with apriltags?

We haven’t done a fault tree, knot chart, 5 whys, or fishbone on this question. I’ve been trying for the last year to get the students to even make the position noise measurements! When looking directly at an April tag the only indicator of distance is the size of the apriltag and that is limited by pixel size&noise. The poor distance estimation was talked a lot with the older limelight2 running at 320x200. This is what our team has. Planning an upgrade but that’s what we have today. The newer cameras/processing power are enabling higher pixel density which will improve precision.

I’ll point to this which shows what I’m talking about

Introduced in 2024, Megatag2 is a precise and ambiguity-free AprilTag-based localizer for mobile robots. It was built with the following goals:

The animation after the line “Notice the difference between MegaTag2”. The Red bumper robot is bouncing closer/farther to the apriltag but the lateral position is very steady. That difference in noise is my focus.

Why not use two apriltag estimates to improve the accuracy? Yes, that would greatly improve accuracy but requires a second camera. We plan to have one camera and in many cases only 1 apriltag is visible in a frame.

In all cases, as long as the sensors are supplying information in the same reference frame (IE, all produce a Pose2d) a simple strategy is to take a weighted average of sensors. Pick your weights to represent how much you trust each source of data.

Yes, but that only works if you have multiple independent Pose2d. What I’m trying to do is a bit different. I will have a distance from the Lidar to a wall near the AprilTag. A camera on the robot will identify the April Tag, the robot distance to the AprilTag, and robot angle to the AprilTag. These are used to determine the Pose2d of the robot (XYR).

If the robot is fairly close to and facing straight at an April Tag there is large error in the distance to the AprilTag and I wish to use lidar to improve that.

See my cartoon with the blue robot facing the Apriltag on a wall. The yellow ellipse indicates the noise in the Apriltag XYR position. There will be much larger uncertainty in the robot to Apriltag distance then in the lateral position.

The lidar info is represented in a green arc with low uncertainty in the distance to the wall/April tag and no knowledge of the lateral position. The comments about lidar uncertainty are well taken.

These sensors appear to complement each other. I’m thinking of combining the data as follows:

Identify the Apriltag

Determine the relative angle of camera and robot to April tag

Measure the lidar distance to the wall/April tag

Make a weighting determination of the Apriltag distance measurement and the lidar distance measurement and combine them.

Then use the Apriltag XYR, angle of the bot, and the distance to determine the robotpose XYR

I’m not very familiar with all the options in WPILib, PhotoVision, etc. I wasn’t sure if there are other, easier ways to combine these data.

[I think the issue is that robotpose is in a cartesian XY coordinate system. But the errors and data I’m concerned about are fundamentally in a cylindrical coordinate system.]

link_counts.title: Robot Localization with MegaTag2 | Limelight Documentation

posts.name: Dylan Powers
posts.cooked:
To answer the final part of your last post. You might wanna take a look at KalmanFilter . Might have what you need.

Otherwise you could woild probably need to do this math on your own.

posts.name: Dylan Powers
posts.cooked: NEW THOUGHT: You could create a Pose2d based on solely the LiDAR measurement by taking the pose of the AprilTag and and translating it by the vector you can create from the tag to your robot using the angle from the camera and distance from lidar. You can then weighted average those within tbe WPILib space and in the field oriented coordinates system.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Lots of info here, and I appreciate the detailed response.

The biggest thing I’d recommend, if you’re having issues with side-to-side variability: First and foremost, make sure you and your students understand the main pose ambiguity issue with apriltags - it’s the optical illusion that cameras see, and is fundamental to the problem of extracting 3-dimensional output from 2-dimensional sensor data.

I’d advise against investing in Lidar - it’s very unproven in FRC (relative to other sensor technologies), and represents a large investment in software and validation before I’d trust it’s a good answer to improve performance.

Instead, spend your time researching wpilib’s Pose Estimators , especially including their latency calculations. Additionally, increase the resolution of your apriltag detection (you want it at max resolution, most likely), and make sure you’re correctly passing the latency numbers into the pose estimator.

Based on what you have told me, it is my belief that that line of thinking will bring you the greatest improvement in pose estimation with the least amount of work.

link_counts.title: What Are AprilTags? — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
WPILib Pose Estimators — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Dylan Powers
posts.cooked:
I agree with @gerthworm 's assessment here when it comes to improving performace in season.

I would encourage you to pursue this in the offseason, however, if your (fellow) students are interested.

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked:
I would probably try and nail down your pose estimation with odometry and vision, then start working on the lidar.

Although I think an easy way to do it is just to take your estimated pose after odometry and vision fusion in the Kalman filter, adjust that to be true to what the lidar tells you as a distance from the wall, and feed it right back in with another addVisionMeasurement() with adjusted standard deviations and some kind of lag calculation.

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: You can use a particle filter for this purpose, as particle filters are typically employed in pose estimation with lidar. Additionally, you can incorporate AprilTag data, since the particle filter primarily calculates the probabilities of each simulated robot pose and resamples them during each iteration. You don’t require an absolute pose as input; instead, you just need a method to determine whether the simulated pose is accurate or not.

posts.name: EricRehder
posts.cooked: Yeah, I described some steps in my bulleted points. I think these are the same, right?

posts.name: EricRehder
posts.cooked:
I appreciate the points about the ambiguity. We’ll emphasize that. If we can get the resolution from camera-april tag that would be great. But to place the coral requires some fine position control.

Why against Lidar? Its not new. My understanding was interfacing to them was a bit complicated, but the new module from Grapple has a CAN interface built in which appears to solve that side.

Powered by Grapple Robotics, the LaserCAN is a LIDAR sensor purpose-built for FRC teams! This postage-stamp sized sensor is capable of detecting objects up to 4m (13 feet!) away (or 1.35m (4.5 feet) in short range mode). It contains an...

Price: USD 42.50

posts.name: EricRehder
posts.cooked: Interesting. I’m interested to see how to “combine” the different sensor data. We’ll read up on these functions.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
EricRehder:

Why against Lidar? Its not new.

I cannot cite a team which has used lidar for localization successfully in a match.

It would be good if someone could correct me with a working example (code and hardware setup), but I do not have one.

Lacking one, I would only be able to recommend it if the team was willing to do the legwork to be first adopter, and all the pain that comes with it.

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: I believe that 254 utilized it in 2018.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
There was one mounted on their robot.

It was a 2d lidar, OP has only referenced 1d lidar.

FRC-2018-Public/src/main/java/com/team254/frc2018/lidar/LidarProcessor.java at master · Team254/FRC-2018-Public · GitHub is a place to start looking in code, but I cannot find how it is actually used for localization. The last reference in their build blog to it indicates they were using idler wheels for odometry, not the lidar.

There is no reference to it in their technical binder or in the CD thread discussing it.

Again, I’m happy to be proven wrong, but I don’t think this fact is useful to OP.

posts.name: Tom Bottiglieri
posts.cooked:
We had mounting provisions for a 2d spinning lidar on the robot. The intention was to measure the height of the scale arms, to see if it was tipped or not. We never ended up using it, and instead went with a vision based solution with a camera in the driver station.

As far as finding distance measurements using only vision with april tag detections, you are likely seeing small errors explode with the solve pnp solution that is used for 3d localization in photon vision and limelight implementations. We mitigated this last year by running multiple different pose estimation models (megatag/solvepnp, pinhole using known mounting height of the tag) and using a simple heuristic to decide which (if any) of the vision model outputs to accept into our pose estimator.  The pinhole model should provide a more accurate “distance from tag” at large distances, but does not provide as rich of a signal. IIRC we found megatag2 to be pretty good at close distances, and would use that to seed our localization pose while sitting on the field before auto mode.

(Link to code , see the shouldUseMegatag and shouldUsePinhole calls for the model choosing heuristic logic)
